p: In 2003, a research group developed and successfully tested a new immunochromatographic assay (ICA), aimed at rapidly and exactly identifying Y. pestis in samples from people suspected of having plague. The technique used monoclonal antibodies to detect the F1 antigen of Y. pestis, as well as rapid diagnostic test (RDT) which was able to give the result after 10–15 min, positivity was defined when the threshold of the antigen concentration was higher than 0.5ng/ml and indicated by two pink lines (Chanteau et al., 2003). This method was applied to ancient human remains, including bone, and dental pulp to reveal that Y. pestis was the cause of the death of plague victims from different sites in Europe (Bianucci et al., 2008, 2009; Haensch et al., 2010) .
